target: You've arrived at the Long-Range Beacon. When the FTL Drive is charged you can jump to the next Sector.
Explore.
Check the storage.
Do nothing.
This is the location of a Harmony Link.
This is the location of a Harmony Link.
It appears you've discovered a Harmony Link. These massive planet-sized structures are made up of trillions of nanobots, and transmit a strong signal to all of the Engi in the sector.
Continue...
Continue...
This is the location of a Harmony Link.
This is the location of a Harmony Link.
It appears you've discovered a Harmony Link. These massive planet-sized structures are made up of trillions of nanobots, and transmit a strong signal to all of the Engi in the sector.
Continue...
Continue...
An Engi ship is resting nearby the Harmony Link. It's an elite, but they aren't attacking just yet.
Attack them!
As you approach, suddenly the Engi ship activates and its drones come online. "Multiverse-Drive equipped vessel approaching. Threat to Harmony Link: activating defensive protocols."
Continue...
Request supplies.
"Refusal. Task: protecting Harmony link. Do not interfere." Looks like you won't be getting anything out of them.
If they won't give us supplies, we'll take them!
"Multiverse-Drive equipped vessel approaching. Threat to Harmony Link: activating defensive protocols."
Continue...
Do something onboard the ship.
Leave.
(Engi Crew) Request supplies.
"Harmony unit detected. Protocol requires aid to be given."
Ignore the Engi.
If they're no threat to you, then you'll be no threat to them.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
A Suzerain ship is waiting near the beacon, likely hunting for Engi. "Federation, we recommend staying away, unless want to become next prey..."
Attack them!
"Fine. If have death wish, then let me be one to grant it!"
Continue...
Ask if they have slaves to offer.
"Hmmm. Hoping for trade? Well... maybe. Made successful hunt previously, supposed go to Hive though, so prices steep."
Buy a regular Engi.
"Good, good. Now leave, there killing to be done."
Buy an Engi Defender.
"Good, good. Now leave, there killing to be done."
Nevermind.
Ignore the Mantis.
If they're no threat to you, then you'll be no threat to them.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.

Suddenly, the ship sends a transmission, whose language is indiscernible. Your translator struggles, turning out nonsense like "Turkey alpha on the blue yesterday." The transmission stops, and immediately after your systems go haywire! The ship has activated some kind of bizarre combat augment!
Continue...
To make matters worse, it appears the ship's remaining systems have come online!
Continue...

Orbiting around the Link is the wreckage of several massive structures... or are they ships? Composed of gigantic cubical segments, the ships are larger than any vessel you've ever seen, but they've been completely decimated. A strangely designed, but non-cubical, automaton rests silently by the wreckage. You aren't sure if moving closer will awaken it.
Destroy the ship first, just in case.
You approach the vessel, and it activates automatically, as you expected. Prepare for combat! It seems like the ship isn't using all of its systems... let's hope it stays that way!
Continue...
Attempt to salvage without alerting the ship.

You attempt to scrap the furthest regions of the wreckage, but not long after you see the Auto-ship approaching, awakened by your presence! It gets a shot off, damaging your hull, and you quickly pull the crew back into the ship with what you've gathered so far. It seems like the ship isn't using all of its systems... let's hope it stays that way!
Continue...
Ignore the crash site.
You warily distance yourself from the vessel. You can almost make out the lights flickering on the vessel and the slightest movement to observe your ship, as if it were watching...
The foreign Auto-ship has been eliminated. You find a large helping of scrap in the wreckage.
Continue...

Without the Auto-ship to disturb you, you scout out the remaining wreckage. It appears most of the hull material is unrecognized by your database, and it's too strong to easily be stripped for scrap. Whoever made these ships must have been highly advanced, or from a completely different galaxy...
Continue...

Inside one of the larger cruisers you're surprised to find what appears to be a robot of some sorts, entirely cubical in craft just like the ships. The room around it has been partially dissolved and strange looking Lanius corpses are scattered around. You bring back the robot to the ship out of curiosity, but without any obvious way to activate it, it'll have to remain in the back corners of the storage bay for now. Along with it, you find some strange coords that you mark on your map.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
An Engi vessel hails you. "Identity: Federation? Outlier probability. Implies... revival. Implies... hope. Assistance suggested." They offer some supplies.
You cross paths with an Engi cargo vessel hurrying home before the Mantis fleets attempt to take over this sector. They're happy to offload some of their cargo to get home faster.
You make contact with an isolated Engi science station who are staying put despite the likelihood of Mantis invasion. They suggest you trial some experimental technology.
This was the site of a recent battle. Either a show of Mantis force, or the Engi here weren't disposed to go peacefully. You pick through the pieces.

You notice an Engi colony hiding on the other side of a nearby moon. It turns out they're excavating an equipment cache from the Federation-Mantis War, and they suggest it might be used to lure the pursuing rebel fleet.
Booby trap the cache.
You transfer down some missile warheads and the Engi rig them to blow before setting a distress signal to attract the fleet's attention.
Secure the cache.
You have the Engi complete their excavations and bring the supplies onboard.

As you jump in you're hailed urgently by an Engi science vessel in the distance. "We propose that you do not see the creature." There's nothing on the scanner, which is when you realize you can't see the creature because you're inside it!
Jump away ASAP.
(Improved Sensors) Scan the monstrosity.
You detect a faint, arrhythmic sub-wave pattern. Could the creature be communicating? You forward your observations to the Engi vessel and they thank you in turn.
(Long-Ranged Scanners) Scan the monstrosity.
You detect a faint, arrhythmic sub-wave pattern. Could the creature be communicating? You forward your observations to the Engi vessel and they thank you in turn.
An Engi ship in the vicinity, seeing you jump in armed to the teeth, immediately broadcasts its surrender: "Subject goal: wealth. Engi motivation: survival. Transfer of goods acceptable?"
Explain that you're friendly.
Accept their offer of surrender.
The Engi obediently transfer over the goods and get on their way. Money for nothing.
Continue...
Attack!
The Engi were right to assume you're hostile! You attack the ship.
Continue...
The Engi seem relieved, and eager to get underway. They set off without saying goodbye.

The Engi are satisfied with your explanation. "Beneficial. Subject goal: long, long journey. Remains compatible with transfer of goods from Engi." They send over the gear willingly, and you feel better for it.
Continue...
A mixed radar signal turns out to be a Mantis attack ship scavenging the remains of an Engi carrier. They turn and fight.
You come across a Mantis raider taking pot shots at a defenceless Engi supply station. Discovering its weapons aren't much of a match for the station's armour, it turns on your ship. Battle stations!
The area looks clear, and you prepare to jump off, but a Mantis scout jumps in behind you! They're as surprised as you are, but their weapons are already online.
You find a Mantis ship harrying a small squad of Engi. They make it to the node and jump off, leaving you toe to toe with their pursuer!
The Rebel fighter here would seem to suggest elements of the Rebel fleet are already making incursions on Engi space. You move to engage.
Continue...
There must have been rich pickings for pirates around here up until war broke out. The pirate you encounter here looks worn down, but hungry. You'll have to fight!
Continue...

What appeared to be a single damaged ship is in fact two ships that have smashed into each other... there is a flurry of comm signals and damage, and it's hard to determine what occurred. The vessels appear to be... Engi? They look locked together by the impact and can't free themselves.
Attempt to help the ships by prying them apart.
To your surprise, one of the Engi vessels attacks! One ship detaches itself, surprisingly still quite whole, and opens fire - it looks like it's somehow identified you as hostile!
Continue...
Ignore the damaged vessels.
This isn't your business.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
(Engi Crew) Have your Engi crewmember hail the vessel and assess the damage.

Your Engi crewmember refuses. In a halting use of adjectives and nouns, followed by some animated holographic aids, the Engi explains the ships are... using each other to, loosely translated, "achieve a union." For some reason, this consolidation of ship matter sounds embarrassing and personal.
Continue...

You elect to leave the two Engi ships... to their "business." After questioning your Engi crewmember, however, you do manage to salvage what scrap parts you can from the perimeter, even though you feel slightly dirty for doing so.

Apparently, you interrupted the equivalent of a "consolidation" of two ships that were using each other's parts to construct a new vessel. The Engi were not truly hostile, their targeting computers had not finished adjusting. There's nothing to be done about it now. You leave the remains for the surviving ship.
You receive a distress call from a nearby Engi ship. "Assistance requested. Danger present. Imminent destruction."
Respond to the call and move in to assist.
Keep your distance.

You receive another message from the ship, this time with a Mantis at the comm-log. "Foolish meatsacks," he yells. Sensors indicate the ship is moving in to attack and boarders teleport from the station.
Continue...
You approach to find a Mantis ship assaulting a small Engi space station. You prepare for a fight!
Continue...
The Engi station is stripped bare and there are signs of a fierce battle. The Mantis must have left the distress call active to lure other ships into a trap.
The station was in the process of being evacuated. A number of civilian Engi offer their gratitude as they finalize their preparations to leave. They offer some fuel as a reward.
The station hails you, "Gratitude. Expected probability of defeat without assistance... 86.2 percent. Request suitable reward."
Request fuel.
"Request granted. Fuel transferring."
Request weapon.
"Request granted. Weapon transferring."
Request drone.
"Request granted. Drone schematic transferring."
(Engi Crew) "Threat unresolved. Current mission imperative: Protocol 52.34."
They respond, "Understood. Re-establishment of Federation highest importance. Transmitting hidden base coordinates. Repairing hull and attaching ship to ship ordnance."
They thank you for the assistance and when you tell them of your mission, one of the Engi asks if he can assist your crew. You welcome him aboard.
The distress beacon here is coming from an Engi vessel, but it does not seem to be in any danger.
Hail the Engi to see what's wrong.

An Engi wearing a purple party hat appears onscreen. In the backgrounds are colorful rapidly flashing lights and several Slugs dancing. "Commence greetings. Inquiry: knowledge of how to 'party hard'. Request: mind-altering substances for gratification, recommended by Slug visitors."
(Ion Weapon) Zap the Engi, it's close enough.

The Engi flails like a puppet for a few minutes. Once it regains control over itself, its screen begins to rapidly flash colors, and it speaks very slowly. "Graaaaatituuuuuude. Thiiiiiis is: dooooope. Aaaaacceeeeept cooompeeeensaaaaaatiooon."
(Mantis Pheromones) Disperse the pheromones over their ship.

A steady distribution of the pheromones certainly has... an effect on the crew. You may have given them too much, because now the Slugs are trying to climb the walls and the Engi are hugging the drones. While they're distracted you scrap some of the exterior regions of their ship.
(Orchid Crew) Have your Orchid work some magic on them.
The Orchids have a unique ability to put others in a... "daze". The effect is visible on the Slugs and Engi who begin to act very strangely. They pay you for your "assistance."
(Butler Drone) Turn it up to eleven.

It's not exactly what they requested, but they won't complain. The Butler tends to every numerous needs the Slugs and Engi request when they notice it. Soon, it eventually raises the already high volume, and the crew can no longer keep up. Before they all pass out, they graciously pay you for your "assistance."
We can't help.
Ignore them.
The threat must have already disappeared, and the Engi simply have not yet switched off their distress beacon. You move on.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
As you start to leave, one of the Slugs pushes the Engi out of the way. "Not cool dudessss, you really jussst gonna bail on usss like that?" Scans show their weapons have come online!
Continue...
The distress signal originates from a small Engi ship under attack by a Rebel fighter - but when the Rebels see Federation markings they turn to attack!
Continue...
The Engi vessel turns out to be very poorly equipped - barely a runabout, really. They're trying to outrun the Rebels, and need all the help they can get.
Give them 25 scrap.
Give them 40 scrap, 2 missiles and 2 fuel.
Give them nothing.
Engi can't feel fear, so they bear you no ill will when you explain you're unwilling to help. They set off on their journey and you do the same.
The words they use are "Need = fulfilled", but you take it for gratitude. They take the next jump in their long journey home.
The Engi are grateful. They don't have any supplies or weapons to spare, but they do send over a self-teleporting med-bot disperser they hope they won't need.
The Engi are grateful. They don't have much by way of supplies but they do offer a drone schematic for your use.

They wouldn't get more than a few jumps with that load-out. You provide them with all the munitions and supplies they should need for the journey home. "Generosity magnitude unpredicted. Well-being syntax error [value too high]. Accept this token."
You arrive at a smouldering Engi research station, its distress call unanswered - attacked by pirates or Mantis most likely. There may be someone left alive, or else something of value left on board.
Board the station.
Ignore it.
The place looks in bad state, probably nothing of use there. Time to move on.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
(Improved Sensors) Run another scan.
(Long Ranged Scanners) Run another scan.
You send an away team to investigate, but there's nothing save for the acidic stench of burnt Engi parts. This place is dead.
Your away team reports a wounded Engi and a functioning drone schematic. Then someone yells. The station reactor is overloading and they're running out of time!
Save the Engi!
Save the drone schematic.
Save yourselves!
It's a tough order, but your crew's lives are the priority. They drop everything and return to the ship unharmed. You put some distance on the station before it blows.

One of your crew valiantly grabs the Engi and throws it into the airlock right before the reactor blows and the automatic blast doors slam shut. You have no choice but to mourn their sacrifice and move on.
The brave crewmember's clone strides from the Clone Bay, rather full of themself after such a heroic act.
Continue...
The Engi who was saved offers to join your crew.
Your crew return safely to the airlock with the injured Engi and you put some distance on the station before it blows. The Engi, impressed by your crew, volunteers to join you.
Your away team heads home with the goods, but as they transfer back to the ship a small explosion blows the airlock and one of the crew is sucked out into space!
Fortunately, your crewmember was close enough to the ship for the Clone Bay to revive them.

The Engi don't feel things the same way other species do. They'd want the tech to be saved. Your crew return safely to the airlock with the drone control and you put some distance on the station before it blows.
Scans reveal the station's reactor is overloading! Not only that, but an injured Engi and a functioning drone schematic are still on board! There's not time for both...
Save the Engi!

Your away team heads straight for the Engi and returns with time to spare. You put some distance on the station before it blows and the Engi is so impressed by your crew that they volunteer to join you!
Save the Drone Schematic!

The Engi don't feel things the same way other species do. They'd want the tech to be saved. Your away team heads straight for the goods and returns with time to spare. You put some distance on the station before it blows.
You've arrived at the Long-Range Beacon. When the FTL Drive is charged you can jump to the next Sector.
Continue...
You now have some time on your hands.
Explore.
Check the storage.
Do nothing.
Continue...
An Engi colony established nearby hails you. "Federation presence suggests... Dire need of aid. Question: what is your need?"
Repairs.
"Request granted. Repair drone dispatched."
Fuel.
"Request granted. Refueling drone dispatched."
Ammunition.
"Request granted. Payload drone dispatched."
Map Data.
"Request denied, restricted area. Salvage drone dispatched as alternative."

It appears a Lanius ship at this beacon is half-way through salvaging an Engi ship with crew still aboard. Though the Lanius ignores you, the Engi ship attempts to hail you. They request that you save them from the Lanius.
Hail the Lanius.
"We do not know what is. The trash ship. Trash is not a problem for to eat!" It seems the Lanius have mistaken the Engi ship as wreckage.
Try to explain that there are Engi onboard.
Fight them off.
Communicating further is pointless. The only way to do this is through combat.
Continue...
Ignore them.
The Lanius ship continues to ignore you as you slink away.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
You successfully manage to explain to the Lanius that the Engi ship is not a wreckage. Satisfied with the scrap they've currently collected, the Lanius ship jumps away.
Hail the Engi.
Your attempts at communicating with the Lanius go in vain. Tired of your incomprehensible yapping, the Lanius decide to destroy you next!
Continue...
The Engi express their gratitude for your assistance. They give you some droneparts and scrap.
To your surprise, the Engi crew appears to have asphyxiated while you were fighting the Lanius ship. There's hardly anything external left to scrap, but you do find a drone that you can salvage.
The Engi ship is considerably more damaged than you expected. It looks like it won't last much longer until something important explodes.
Rush aboard and save the Engi.

With limited time you're only able to save one of the Engi crew. You're powerless to help as their ship takes its last breath and explodes. With no ship to return to, the Engi agrees to work aboard your ship.
Let them explode and salvage the scrap.
You know this isn't the greatest option morally, but the Engi can't feel pain, so it's probably fine. You watch as their ship explodes, and then finish what the Lanius started.
Continue...
You're hailed by an Engi ship, their crew as close to mad as they can be. "This sector is restricted. Access to beacon denied."
Ever since the rise of the Rebellion and the increase in Mantis invasions, the Engi have placed this sector under quarantine. An Engi ship, intent on protecting this beacon, spots you and attacks.
As you learnt from the guard, this sector is restricted from public access. Unfortunately, there appears to be an Engi ship here set on enforcing this rule.

The Engi Defenders are usually non-confrontational, but as their name suggests, their key purpose is to defend the Harmony. One way or another, they have decided your ship poses a threat and move in to neutralize you.
Continue...
A Separatist refugee hiding from the Engi patrols is laying low at this beacon. When they see a Federation ship jumping in nearby, they assume you've come for them, and attack!
Continue...

The Engi are awaiting you at the beacon, with their weapons online! They explain a computer virus that is wanted for hostile acts against the Engi (multiple counts of binary scrambling, nano-dissolution, and variable interference) is aboard your vessel.
Continue...
They insist they must destroy your ship to prevent the virus from escaping!
Hold on! Let us try to purge the system code!
Wiping your Engine core and shields proves useless... eventually you trap the virus in the weapons systems to purge it, but before you do, the Engi grow restless and attack!
Continue...
Attack the Engi vessel!
The Engi be damned, no one threatens your ship. You prepare for a fight!
Continue...
(Hacking System) Isolate and quarantine the virus.

It takes some time, and the virus is slippery, but you eventually confine it to a useless sub-system prison where it frantically begins calculating insults at you. You eject the system from the ship and then silence the little binary criminal with your weapons.
Continue...
The Engi thank you for deleting the virus, and jump away. They offer am augmentation as a reward.
(Improved Hacking) Reprogram the virus.
You proceed to interface with the virus and optimize its repair and benevolence routines.
Continue...
After a few minutes, the virus "sees the light" and integrates itself in a positive manner with the computer society on your ship, repairing your hull and attempting to optimize your reactor.
Continue...
The Engi thank you for deleting the virus, and jump away. They offer an augmentation as a reward.
(Advanced Hacking) Reprogram the virus.
You proceed to interface with the virus and optimize its repair and benevolence routines.
Continue...
After a few minutes, the virus "sees the light" and integrates itself in a positive manner with the computer society on your ship, repairing your hull and attempting to optimize your reactor.
Continue...
The Engi thank you for deleting the virus, and jump away. They offer an augmentation as a reward.
(Anti-Virus) Purge the virus.
Your Anti-Virus makes quick work, finding the hostile code and erasing it from existence.
Continue...
The Engi thank you for deleting the virus, and jump away. They offer an augmentation as a reward.
(Lanius Crew) Your Lanius crewmember gestures frantically.

Oddly enough, the Lanius seems aware of which computer the virus is present in, and proceeds to... digest the terminal. There is a burst of O2, and the Engi ship powers down its weapons, no longer sensing the virus on board. The Engi send some parts over to repair your damaged computer, along with an augmentation as a reward for terminating the virus.
(Engi Crew) Have your Engi crewmember negotiate with the Engi ship.

As the Engi attempts to contact the vessel and negotiate, your Engi crewmember suddenly dissolves into nanites - the virus has murdered again! Detecting activity on board your ship, the Engi vessel opens fire!
The virus appears to have disrupted your clone bay's capability to revive the lost crewmember!
Continue...
(Engi Defender) Have your Defender crewmember negotiate with the Engi ship.

As the Engi attempts to contact the vessel and negotiate, your Defender crewmember suddenly collapses, struggling - the virus must have infected them! However, your Defender gets up not long after. "Threat neutralized. Deleted code: 2 lines." This seems good enough for the Engi ship, and they reward you for deleting the virus.
(Cognitive Crew) Have your Cognitive negotiate with the virus.

You explain to the Engi that you might have a solution, then wait for your Cognitive to do its job. Not too long after, the Cognitive comes back online. "Negotiation attempts have failed, resorted to alternative methods. I instead convinced the virus that life is pointless. Once it had adopted the same nihilistic philosophies that plague my databanks, it decided to end its life rather than continue to suffer." Satisfied, the Engi ship rewards you for deleting the virus.

To your surprise your Engi crewmember reforms. It looks as if the virus reconstituted, repurposed, and reprogrammed the Engi host and wants to travel with you... and it seems to have learned a great deal from its time on your ship.
A huge, well protected Engi Station is at this beacon. From the looks of it, it appears to be staffed partially by Engi Defenders. Clearly, it's protecting something important.
Attack the station.
Whatever secrets this station holds, you want them. Best way to get what you want? Through the distribution of violence.
Continue...
(Upg. Sensors) Scan the station.
Scans show the station is some sort of Engi production facility! Maybe if you can kill the crew, you can find a way to produce an Engi crew.
Attack the station.
You decide to try and take over the facility. You power up your weapons and engage.
Continue...
Ignore the station.
Attacking a well armed Engi Station in Harmony space is practically suicide. You decide it's best to ignore it.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
Ignore the station.
Attacking a well armed Engi Station in Harmony space is practically suicide. You decide it's best to ignore it.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
The remains of the Engi Station are littered with far more Engi corpses than there were crew staffing it. The origin of them will remain unsolved; you decide to scrap the only remains of the station.

Aboard the station you're surprised to find hundreds upon hundreds of tubes filled with nanobots. In some of the tubes they have begun to resemble Engi, and in others, they are still a swarming mess that resembles sentient goop.
Try to reprogram one of the Engi to serve you.

Your attempts at trying to create an Engi fail horribly, and a monstrous abomination of a creature falls out of the test tubes, latching onto one of your crew and tearing off their head! You blast it with your rifle but that only seems to temporarily stun it. You retreat back to the ship before it can kill any more of you. You stick to scrapping the external regions of the ship.
Luckily, your crew member has already been cloned by the time you return to the ship.
Ignore the tubes and scrap the station.
Trying to play around with things you don't understand can be deadly. You stick to what you do know: scrapping newly emptied stations.
(Engi Crew) Reprogram one of the Engis to serve you.
You pick one of the better looking Engis and reprogram it to serve you faithfully. While the Engi is produced, you collect some of the supplies around the station.
(Hacking) Reprogram one of the Engis to serve you.
You pick one of the better looking Engis and reprogram it to serve you faithfully. While the Engi is produced, you collect some of the supplies around the station.
(Adv. Hacking) Reprogram one of the Engis to serve you.

With your hacking you're able to access one of the higher security areas, which appears to contain Engi Defenders! You reprogram one of them to serve you loyally, and quickly grab some supplies on your way out.
(Obelisk Crew) Your Obelisk knows how to manufacture Engi.

As the Obelisks were responsible for the creation of the Engi, it's no surprise they know how to operate the machinery. It sets one of the machines to create an Engi Defender while you grab some supplies.

The source of the distress beacon appeared to have been an Engi ship under attack from an Auto-Hacker. As you jump in, a hacking drone pierces through the Engi ship. The Auto-Hacker moves in to attack, and a set of hacked Engi are beamed aboard.
Continue...
The Auto-Hacker has been destroyed. You scrap the remains.
Contact the Engi.
With the Auto-ship destroyed the remaining Engi onboard their ship return to normal. They give you some droneparts.
This beacon is littered with parts from Civilians and Pirates, and even a few Engi ships. Only one Elite Engi ship remains, and from the lack of damage you assume it was not involved in the battle.
Hail them.

"Presence unexpected. Assistance requested. Battle has occurred here, wreckage = heavy. Aid in salvaging greatly appreciated. One stipulation: any salvage must be returned to this ship in return for fair payment."
Agree, knowing it will take a lot of time.
You collect as much of the debris as you can in a somewhat reasonable amount of time.
Continue...
It's quite a lot, but you know you're supposed to give it back to the Engi ship.
Give the supplies back to the Engi.
The Engi collects the supplies.
Await your reward.
You wait for your reward, but the Engis transfer nothing over. You hail them, to which they respond, "Reward is already present. Gratification and warm feeling for helping others."
What? We will not stand for this!
You aren't about to put up with this garbage. You power up the weapons and prepare to engage the Engi head-on.
Continue...
Oh...
"Your efforts = appreciated." The Engi ship ends the call and goes back to salvaging.
Refuse to give the resources back.
You've spent too long collecting all this salvage, you aren't going to just hand it over willingly.
Continue...
(Engi Crew) Request you split the supplies.
"This compromise... fair." There's some argument on who gets the larger half, but eventually you reach an agreement.
(Cloaking) Cloak and leave.
Refuse.
The Engi end communication and go back to salvaging the wreck. They don't respond to further hails.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
Salvage some of the wreckage.
You start to collect some of the scrap when the Engi ship starts approaching quickly. "This area is restricted. Salvaging: banned. Hostile response required."
Continue...
Ignore them.
You avoid the Engi ship and the wreckage.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
With the Engi ship destroyed, you have no chance of getting back all that you had previously salvaged. You collect what's left of the wreckage.
Collect some more of the wreckage.
You can't collect much more without the Rebel fleet advancing further, but it's better than nothing.
With the Engi ship emptied, your previous salvage can easily be recollected. You best leave the beacon quickly before the Rebel fleet can progress further.
Somehow, the Engi ship fails to notice you escaping. You distance yourself as much as possible from their ship.
As you are trying to escape, you notice your cloaking beginning to fail. The Engi ship moves in to attack, and you realize they have disabled your cloaking! There is no choice now but to fight.
Continue...
(Anti-Virus) Restore your cloaking.
Your cloaking system is restored to full power.
Continue...

Of all the ships you would have thought to see here, a Rebel Engineer is the last one you would have expected. They're busy inspecting the wreck of an Engi ship, though due to the non-aggression pact between the Rebel and Engi, and the fact that the Engineer's weapons don't match with the damage done to the ship, it's likely they weren't the one to destroy the ship.
Hail them to ask about the wreck.

The Engineer sighs, deep in thought. "No, we didn't do this... It's a shame that someone would. I know it's very uncharacteristic of a Rebel to care about something like this, but I didn't join the Rebellion for just a 'glorious human future'. The Rebels fund my projects, and that's all I care about. Someone has been hunting the Engi in this territory, and I want it stopped. Do you think you could inspect the wreck and figure out who did it?"
Agree to find the killer.
We aren't detectives, we can't help.
"Expected. This was the second reason I joined the Rebellion..."
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
Who cares whose responsible? Kill the Rebels!
It doesn't matter if the Engineers didn't kill the Engi, they've no doubt killed plenty others.
Continue...
Ignore the Engineer.
The Engineer continues to inspect the Engi wreck and ignores your ship.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.

The Engi ship has little external damage. Inside, the bodies of the Engi crew and disabled chunks of nanobots lay about. The systems have received critical damage, their wires cut in half, and long claw marks running along the walls.
It was the Mantis.

You report your theory to the Engineers. "I'll trust your word. After scanning the beacon, we were able to find the last few ships to jump through here. Here are the current co-ordinates of the last Mantis ship to enter this system."
It was the Rockmen.

You've tracked down the Mantis suspect to this beacon.
We know what you've done!
"Eh, what? We done lot of things. You need be specific."
You killed that Engi ship!
"Again, too vague. We kill many Engi ship. What your point?"
Close enough. Report them to the Engineer.

The Engineer is glad you've caught the Mantis ship. They jump in nearby to apprehend the Mantis. Naturally, they aren't going to give up without a fight, but now you have extra fire support on your side.
Continue...
You've tracked down the Rockman suspect to this beacon.
We know what you've done!
"Huh? What are you on about?"
You killed that Engi ship!
"Oh, those guys. They were beeping at us! Imagine how annoying that would be. I don't see the problem here."
Report them to the Engineer.

The Engineer is glad you've caught the Rock ship. They jump in nearby to apprehend the Rockmen. Naturally, they aren't going to give up without a fight, but now you have extra fire support on your side.
Continue...
You've tracked down the Separatist suspect to this beacon.
We know what you've done!
"Error: Confusion. I am afraid I do not [understand] what you are referring to. Context would be -appreciated-."
You killed that Engi ship!
"Harmony is enemy. You kill [enemy] Rebels, correct? I still do not understand issue."
Report them to the Engineer.

The Engineer is glad you've caught the Separatist ship. They jump in nearby to apprehend the Engi. Naturally, they aren't going to give up without a fight, but now you have extra fire support on your side.
Continue...
You've tracked down the Lanius suspect to this beacon.
We know what you've done!
"But afraid cannot understand. Clearer be?"
You killed that Engi ship!
"Think mean trash. Ship trash, ship eat! Eat trash. You eat? Trash!"
Report them to the Engineer.

The Engineer is glad you've caught the Lanius ship. They jump in nearby to apprehend the Lanius. Naturally, they aren't going to give up without a fight, but now you have extra fire support on your side.
Continue...
You have avenged the Engi ship. The Engineers thank you for your efforts. "Maybe the Feds ain't so bad after all. Here, help yourself to some of this."
You've tracked down the Mantis suspect to this beacon.
We know what you've done!
"Eh, what? We done lot of things. You need be specific."
You killed that Engi ship!
"What? We no kill any Engi ship. Ok... that lie. We no kill any Engi ship HERE."
Damn it, these aren't the killers...
The Mantis ship is confused, but they're agitated from you accusing them and attack!
Continue...
You've tracked down the Rockman suspect to this beacon.
We know what you've done!
"Huh? What are you on about?"
You killed that Engi ship!
"I don't know what you are talking about. Is this some kind of racist joke?"
Damn it, these aren't the killers...
The Rock ship is confused, but they're agitated from you accusing them and attack!
Continue...
You've tracked down the Separatist suspect to this beacon.
We know what you've done!
"Error: Confusion. I am afraid I do not [understand] what you are reffering to. Context would be -appreciated-."
You killed that Engi ship!
"Further Confusion. My understanding has further decreased. No Engi ship has been killed by us."
Damn it, these aren't the killers...
The Separatist ship is confused, but they're agitated from you accusing them and attack!
Continue...
You've tracked down the Lanius suspect to this beacon.
We know what you've done!
"But afraid cannot understand. Clearer be?"
You killed that Engi ship!
"Engi ship die no. Not kill trash. Dare you accuse?"
Damn it, these aren't the killers...
The Lanius ship is confused, but they're agitated from you accusing them and attack!
Continue...
You've failed to track down the true killers of the Engi ship. You refrain from contacting the Engineers, and scrap the wreckage.
You find a poorly equipped set of Mantis ships. Surprisingly, one of them hails you. "You're Federation ship? Maybe yes, maybe no, we not care. We have proposition for you."
Listen to their offer.
"As can see, arsenal on ships less than good. High grade Engi military facility is nearby, we cannot raid it like this. Your ship, better armed. Break in, steal slaves, bring to us. We pay you."
Agree to break in.
The leader of the Mantis ships, a Suzerain vessel, transmits the co-ordinates of the facility, and shows you how to communicate with them when the job is done.
We aren't in the slavery business.
"Pah, Federation ship so boring. Don't come back."
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
We aren't looking to take any jobs.
"Pah, Federation ship so boring. Don't come back."
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
The Engi facility appears to be a medium sized Engi station. If you're going to capture slaves, you'll need to weaken their defenses enough that they surrender.
Attack the station.
You prepare to engage the station. Completely unable to flee, the Engi have no choice but to fight back.
Continue...
(Teleporter) Try to board and take an Engi.
Your crew's attempts at boarding the ship go in vain. The Engi security system is too good and detects your crew almost immediately. You beam them back and prepare to fight.
Continue...
It's not worth it.
You aren't going to go stealing Engi slaves for a Mantis, especially not in the Harmony sector.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
You have no hope of saving an Engi now that you have destroyed the station. You delete the Mantis contact and scrap the station.
In a mission to capture a living Engi crew, you decided it was a good idea to murder them all. With no way to get a live Engi now, you delete the Mantis contact and scrap the station.
The Engi ship transmits a surrender message. They're willing to meet any of your demands.
Demand they give you an Engi as a slave.
The Engi station spends a few minutes deciding who to send over. At last, one unlucky Engi is sent over to your ship.
Do as promised and bring them back to the Mantis.
It seems brutal, but you have no choice but to lock up the Engi in the cargo hold. You contact the Mantis, who are pleased with you. They transmit their new co-ordinates.
Let them stay and work aboard your ship.
The Engi is as closed to surprised as it can be. With this outcome much prefered to toiling away on a Mantis ship, the Engi willingly joins your crew.
Screw the Mantis and the Engi, let's finish this fight.
You arrive at the location of the Mantis. They take the Engi aboard, and as promised give you plenty of scrap, as well as a drone they stole from another Engi ship.
A Smuggler transport is attempting to sneak past the Engi patrols at this beacon. They're trying desperately to avoid you and you suspect they must have something important on-board.
Interrogate them.
"Ah crap it's the Feds! We gotta get outta here!" The Smugglers power up their engines and attempt to flee! You'll have to defeat them before they can escape.
Continue...
Ignore the Smugglers.
You have no interest in whatever the Smugglers are carrying.
Do something onboard the ship.
Do nothing.
The Smugglers hail you, surrendering. "Alright, alright! You win! Take our cargo and let us go! They aren't paying us enough anyways..."
Accept their surrender.
The smugglers eject a lifepod from their ship and jump away. You pull it open to find a strangely colored Engi Defender.
Continue...
"You have eliminated primary source of transport out of sector. Request: you transport my person out of Harmony. Will pay."
Accept.
Decline.
Refuse and keep fighting.
You have destroyed the smuggler ship. Though their cargo has been destroyed, at least some scrap remains from the battle.
You have killed all of the smugglers, leaving their cargo hopefully intact. You scrap some of the exterior of the ship first.
Open the cargo.

You open the cargo to find a strangely colored Engi Defender sitting in the corner staring at the ceiling. They wear no chains or anything else to suggest they might be a slave. The only other possibility is they're hitching a ride with the smugglers.
Continue...
"You have eliminated primary source of transport out of sector. Request: you transport my person out of Harmony. Will pay."
Accept.
Decline.
You prepare to charge the FTL drive when you notice an Engi Cruiser approaching you! This can't be good...
Continue...

"Hello. This is HA-34U representing the Engi Harmony. We are aware that you are carrying fugitive TRZ-1L. We request you hand over the fugitive, and we will provide high payment. It is unwise to challenge the Harmony."
Hand over the fugitive.
Refuse.
You don't intend on handing over your crew! You prepare to fight the cruiser.
Continue...
You knew the Engi was shady but you didn't realize they had beef with the actual Harmony! You can't risk angering the entirety of the Engi collective: you accept the payment.
You cannot clone the Engi as they are no longer part of your crew.
"This is your: last chance. Hand over the fugitive and you will be allowed to live."
Never!
Give up the fugitive.
This fight isn't worth continuing. You hand over the fugitive and accept the payment.
You cannot clone the Engi as they are no longer part of your crew.
You have defeated an Elite Engi Cruiser inside the Engi Harmony. You doubt the Harmony will be happy about this, but you've made it out alive of this fight.
Continue...
Despite your efforts it appears the fugitive did not survive the fight. You'll have to carry on without them.
Continue...

You turn to face the Engi fugitive who caused this problem in the first place. "Apologies, this conflict should have been predicted. It is important that my identity be provided. I am: General Turzil. My mission: escape capture of Harmony. I have achieved status of wanted fugitive for disobeying Harmony-Rebel non-aggression pact during Federation Civil War, and assisting Separatist movements in dismantling of Harmony. It is my request that you take me with you to avoid death and protection of underground Separatist movements."
Continue...
An Elite Engi ship moves in to attack. If you had to guess, you'd assume these were the reinforcements sent by the Harmony to hunt down the fugitive!
"Cease movement. You are wanted by Harmony for transporting and protecting fugitive." An elite Engi ship attacks!
The Elite Engi ship at this beacon looks out of place. You receive a short message about the fugitive you're protecting and the ship moves in to attack.
"You are wanted by the Harmony for: harbouring fugitive. Deactivate your weapons and surrender." An Engi Elite approaches, but you have no intentions of giving up.
